results.title: Very good friends
results.creator_credit: Richard Bennett, Martin Tahse, Learning Corporation of America and Martin Tahse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learning to be human”.
Based on the novel “Beat the Turtle Drum” by Constance Greene. Deals with a thirteen-year-old girl’s reactions to the death of her younger sister, to whom she was very close. Starring Melissa Sue Anderson, Katy Kurtzman.

results.title: Vertical spindle moulding machine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Woodworking machinery series”
Short description of machine, moulding and rabbeting stiles, rails and bar of sash. Setting the cutters, use of face board. Franking, cutting tenons to length. Other uses, the Whitehall cutter block, French or slotted head.

results.title: Vertical
results.creator_credit: David Hall and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Both a simple catalogue of verticals and a series of visual paradoxes exploring illusions of straightness and squareness and the notion of frame. A stimulus film showing recurrence of geometrics in nature. No dialogue.

results.title: Versailles: the palace of the sun
results.brief_description: Presents the man-made beauties of the Palace of Versailles, built for the “Sun-King”, Louis XIV. Shows the famous Hall of Mirrors. Lingers on the many works of sculpture and shows the Trianons, the Queen’s Hamlet, and the great gardens designed by La Notre.

results.title: Versailles
results.brief_description: Beautiful Versailles perpetuates the history of France. This silent film with English intertitles includes a brief look at the 17th century Palace of Versailles, its history and its architecture.

results.title: Vers le Realisme Poetique (1936-1938) Pt. 5
results.brief_description:
Part 5 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. The term ‘Poetic Realism’ was originally applied to literature; in the cinema it was first used in relation to Pierre Chenal’s ‘La rue sans nom’ (1933). It is a critical construction with blurred edges - terms such as ‘populist melodrama’, ‘the social fantastic’, ‘noir realism’ and ‘magic realism’ can also apply. However, ‘Poetic Realism’ designates pessimistic urban dramas, usually set in Paris (though there were colonial examples) in working class settings, with doomed narrative often tinged with criminality. The supreme examples are the films of Marcel Carne and Jacques Prevert - ‘Quai des Brumes’ (1938), ‘Le jour se leve’ (1939) - but the canon aso includes Jean Vigo’s ‘L’Atalante’ (1934), Jean Renoir’s ‘La bete humaine’ (1938), Jacques Feyder’s ‘Le grand jeu’ (1933), Julien Duvivier’s ‘La belle equipe’ (1936) and Jean Gremillon’s ‘Gueule d’amour’ (1937); to which could be added Marie Epstein’s ‘La maternelle’ (1933). As its name indicates, Poetic Realism proposes a duality between the everyday and the lyrical/emotional, the poetry arising precisely from the everyday, from a world created - beyond individual directors - by an execptional ensemble of craftsmen and artists: the decors of Alexandre Trauner, the dialogues of Prevert, Charles Spaak and Henri Jeanson, the photography of Jules Kruger, Eugen Shufftan, Curt Courant, the music of Maurice Jaubert and Joseph Kosma ; and of course, the stars: Jean Gabin, but also Arletty, Jules Berry, Charles Vanel and others. It was a highly stylised world, both in its mise en secne and in its ‘mythical’ characters, yet the box-office success of the films show that they ‘spoke’ to their popular audience.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘The companion to French cinema’. BFI Publishing, 1996. Further reading: Dudley Andrews. ‘Mists of regrets: culture and sensibility in classic French film’. Princeton University Press, 1995. =Held in our collection.

Credits: director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Casard.
Interviewees include: Rene Clair, Pierre Braunberger, Marcel L’Herbier, Yves Allegret, Henri-George Clouzot, Claude Autant-Lara, Raoul Ploquin, Charles Spaak, Marcel Carne.

results.title: Vers des Temps Nouveaux = Towards a New Age
results.brief_description:
The plague epidemic has left a lasting impression in the minds of the artists. At the end of the XIVth century the christianity revealed in the new secularised art is truggling with the eternal question: what happens to the body after death? Major art works of this period are no longer cathedrals or palaces, they are tombs. People want imposing resting places and funeral art evolves from a simple head stone to mausoleums and chapels in which the iconographies features rituals of death (such as embalming) and realistic representation of dead bodies. The centre of artistic innovation has shifted to Florence and to the Duchy of Burgundy. The most important signs of a change of direction in art occur in sculpture, with Claus Sluter in Dijon and Donatello in Florence. Major works featured in this episode include: Giotto’s frescos for the Scrovegni Chapel in Padua, the mausoleum for Cardinal de la Grange, Donatello’s statue of St Georges and Sluter’s Well of Moses.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Verdict at 1.32
results.creator_credit: Charles Davis, Burt Martin and International Temperance Society
results.brief_description: Dramatically depicts the effects of alcohol, stressing that consuming even the smallest quantities of alcohol can be dangerous. Tells the story of a young secretary who has two cocktails while out to lunch with her fiance. Her reaction dulled when driving back to work, she cannot brake in time and is killed, killing another person, also an alcoholic. Subsequently both their brains are examined by a neurologist; and the effects of alcohol on reaction times and normal co-ordination, convincingly demonstrated at a physiology lecture and a sports car gymkhana.

results.title: Verbal communication: the power of words
results.creator_credit: Stephen Judson, Peter Jordan and CRM Productions
results.brief_description: Uses animation, humorous vignettes, and dramatized slices of organizational life to illustrate the four critical parts of every verbal exchange: the speaker, the language used, the atmosphere, and the listener. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
